Agriculture accounts for 39% of the national gross domestic product 
(GDP), and employs about 70% of the total workforce. Rural income 
is  primarily  generated  from  agriculture,  which  is  dominated  by  rice 
production.  Despite  the  importance  and  potential  of  agriculture,  its

growth  of  agriculture  was  less  than  3.0%  per  annum  (with  high 
variability), which was far below the plan target of 5.2% per annum, 
and had no substantial impact on poverty reduction in rural areas.

Risks and Safeguards  ASDP's  basic  assumption  is  the  continued  commitment  of  the 
Government  to  make  agriculture  more  productive  and  stable  by 
facilitating  agricultural  commercialization  and  diversification.  The 
Government's  strong  commitment  is  reflected  in  its  development 
policy letter for ASDP. 
 
Risks are mainly related to difficulties anticipated in (i) approval and 
implementation  of  subdecrees  related  to  social  and  economic  land 
concessions,  and  (ii)  divestment  of  public  enterprises.  The 
implementation of subdecrees related to social  and economic land 
concessions involves difficult political processes and a large number 
of  stakeholders.  The  Government  must  establish  procedures  to 
screen  potential  concession  programs  to  ensure  the  proper  use  of 
available and unused state land for productive purposes and for the 
benefit  of  poor  farmers.  Competition  for  such  land  should  be 
adequately  controlled.  ADB  is  helping  the  Government  establish 
implementation guidelines for the social land concession subdecree 
and  formulate  a  draft  subdecree  on  economic  land  concessions 
through  an  ongoing  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  land  legislation. 
ADB  will  also  provide  TA  in  conjunction  with  ASDP  to  ensure  close 
monitoring  of  ASDP  implementation  and  conduct  effective  dialogue 
with  the  Government.  ADB  will  closely  coordinate  with  the  World 
Bank,  which  will  initiate  the  social  land  concession  program  on  a 
small-scale pilot basis. 
 
There  is  a  wide  consensus  within  the  Government  on  the  need  for 
early divestment of agricultural public enterprises. ADB was informed 
that  the  highest  authority  of  the  Government  decided  on  early 
divestment,  and  initiated  the  process  for  carrying  out  external 
auditing  of  public  enterprises.  ADB  engaged  in  a  long  and  careful 
dialogue  with  the  enterprises  during  program  formulation  and  loan 
processing  to  ensure  that  the  Government  provides  adequate 
safeguards  for  staff  to  be  separated  as  a  result  of  enterprise 
divestment.  A  resettlement  policy  framework  has  been  agreed  on 
with the Government to address any adverse social impacts that may 
result  from  any  involuntary  acquisition  of  productive  opportunities 
and  displacement  of  smallholders  due  to  changes  in  land  use.  The 
TA,  proposed  in  conjunction  with  ASDP,  will  provide  technical  and 
advisory  support  to  help  the  Government  complete  divestment  of 
public enterprises during the program period.

Poverty  is  particularly  prevalent  among  vulnerable  groups  affected  by  the  long  civil  conflict: 
internally displaced people, returned refugees, and war widows. 
 
4. 
Reducing poverty by emphasizing rural development was the primary development goal 
of  the  First  Socioeconomic  Development  Plan  (SEDPI,  1996–2000),  which  highlighted  food 
security  and  transition  to  market-based  agriculture.  Key  components  of  SEDPI  included  (i) 
provision  of  better  access  to  improved  agricultural  inputs;  (ii)  improvement  in  rice yields and 
reduction  in  production  loss  due  to  irregular  weather  conditions;  (iii)  promotion  of  livestock 
production,  particularly  by  improving  animal  health;  and  (iv)  promotion  of  commercialized 
agriculture.  Central  to  this  were  institutional,  regulatory,  and  policy  reforms  to  introduce  a 
framework conducive to market-based agricultural growth. 
 
5.

per  annum  on  average  (with  high  variability),  well  below  the  SEDPI  targets.  Overall  poverty  in 
Cambodia is  estimated  to  have  declined  during  the  SEDPI  period  but  this  was  largely  due  to 
significant reduction in urban poverty led by the growth of the garment sector. Slow agricultural 
growth  means  that  the  sector  provided  no  major  impetus  to  reduce  rural  poverty,  and  the 
linkage between agriculture and the rest of the rural economy was thought to have weakened. 
Many  of  the  new  entrants  to  the  labor  force  have  thus  had  to  be  absorbed  into  relatively 
unproductive employment in agriculture.

Government  recognizes  that  reforms  needed  deepening  to  fully  capture  the  benefits  of

Under  the  2001  Land  Law,  land  concessions  should  not  exceed  10,000  ha  unless 
justified by evidence of actual investment and needs. This limit is to be applied to existing and 
new  concessions,  necessitating  renegotiation  of  concession  contracts  and  revocation  of

productive economic concessions and to allocate land to the landless. There will be a potential 
for increasing various income-generating activities for the poor, and examples of the integration 
of  smallholder  and  estate  agriculture  can  be  found  across  Southeast  Asia.  The  Government 
thus  recognizes  the  need  to  (i)  reduce  unused  economic  land  concessions,  (ii)  further 
accelerate the securing of land titles for farmers, and (iii) implement the 2001 Land Law through 
the issuance of necessary subdecrees and guidelines. 
 
14.  Most  crop  production  in  Cambodia  is  rain-fed.  Irrigation  is  often  supplementary  and 
season-specific  rather  than  year-round.  Even  this  supplementary  irrigation  is  limited,  covering 
only  16%  of  the  total  rice  growing  area.  In  addition,  a  flood  recession  system  of  production  is 
used on 7% of the area. As a result, almost all rice is single-cropped and highly dependent on 
rainfall. Under the first ASP, new approaches to irrigation management and maintenance were 
tested  based  on  the  formation  of  farmers'  water  user  communities  (FWUCs).  Eleven  pilot 
schemes  are  being  pursued  under  the  MAFF's  medium-term  work  program  for  2001–2005. A 
water  law  is  being  reviewed  at  the  National  Assembly,  and  a  new  statement  on  water  policy 
drafted,  incorporating  the  commitment  and  mechanisms  for  sustainable  small-  and  medium-
scale  irrigation  schemes.  In  parallel,  the  Government  is  increasing  investment  in  irrigation 
projects with assistance from bilateral and multilateral funding agencies, including ADB. 
 
15. 
Farmers'  access  to  improved  seeds  and  other  inputs  is  still  limited  due  to  their  lack  of 
awareness  of  the  benefits  of  using  improved  seeds  and  other  required  inputs.  Im portant 
contributions are being made to the production and dissemination of improved rice seeds by the 
Cambodian  Agricultural  Research  and  Development  Institute  (CARDI)  with  support  from  the 
Australian  Agency  for  International  Development  and  by  the  World  Bank’s  Agricultural 
Productivity Improvement Project. However, total production of improved rice seeds is still small 
(about 400 tons), barely enough to cover the needs of most farmers. To improve the legal and 
institutional framework for seed production and distribution, the Government is drafting a seed 
law,  which  aims  to  promote  the  private  sector's  role  in  improving  seed  production  and 
distribution. This is an important step to initiate the promotion of the seed and planting materials 
industry  in  Cambodia.  Other  important  areas  also  need  to  be  addressed:  quality  control 
measures, regulatory enforcement mechanisms and capacity building. The projects financed by 
other funding agencies are involved in these areas. The Government also issued a subdecree 
and established the Bureau of Agricultural Materials Standards within MAFF in October 1998 to 
provide a regulatory framework to protect farmers and other users of agricultural inputs (seeds, 
fertilizers,  pesticides,  veterinary  medicines,  feeds  and  feed  additives)  from  adulteration, 
commercial  exploitation  and  dangers  to  health  as  a  result  of  low-quality  products  and 
inappropriate packaging. Much remains to be done, particularly to address issues such as the 
presence  of  unmarked  and  concentrated  chemicals,  and  over-adulteration  of  products,  by 
strengthening the bureau's capacity and raising awareness of these issues among farmers.

3. 

Market Environment for Private Agro-Based Enterprises 

17. 
During  the  first  ASP  period,  the  Government  initiated  steps  for  withdrawing  its  direct 
intervention  in  production  and  marketing  of  agricultural  and  agro-based  products.  In  the 
agriculture  sector,  the  Government  owns  seven  rubber  estates,  Agricultural  Inputs  Company 
(AIC),  and  Kampuchea  Fish  Import  and  Export  Company  (KAMFIMEX).  While  SOREs  remain 
active  producers  constituting  about  80%  of  the  total  rubber  exploited  area  of  the  country,  the 
other  two  enterprises'  activities  have  been  significantly  curtailed  as  private  companies  have 
increased  their  market  shares.  SOREs  have  been  posting  losses  for  a  number  of  years  and 
appear  to  drain  resources  from  the  rubber  sector.  Continued  state  ownership  impedes  the 
growth  of  the  whole  rubber  sector  by  restricting  development  of  smallholder  or  family  rubber 
producers  and  by  constraining  smallholder  processing  and  marketing  of  rubber.  The  impaired 
quality of estate rubber also constrains the promotion of Cambodian rubber in the international 
market.  It  is  reported  that  this  results  in  the  lower  price  of  Cambodian  rubber  by  15–20% as 
compared  to  that  of  other  countries'  rubber,  which  is  certified  for  international  standards,  and 
seriously  affects  smallholders'  income.  Thus,  SOREs'  operationally  and  financially  poor 
performance hinders efficient use of resources and points to a lost opportunity for development. 
 
18. 
State ownership of AIC and KAMFIMEX also uses scarce public resources for redundant 
operations, and provides uncertainty in the agricultural input and output markets about possible 
state  interventions  in  future.  Bureaucratic  procedures  and  informal  government  pressures  for 
social  and  political  imperatives  restrict  the  day-to-day management of public enterprises. AIC, 
which is supposed to distribute agricultural inputs, has not had any business recently and has 
been  paying  administrative  expenses,  including  salaries  of  its  55  staff,  from  the  receipt  of 
interest on cash assets. Given that the private sector sufficiently meets input supply, there is no 
clear  justification  for  the  state  ownership  of  AIC,  and  the  Government  recognizes  the  need  to 
facilitate AIC's divestment. KAMFIMEX had a monopoly of fish exports until 2000, when export 
of  live  fish  and  fish  products  was  liberalized.  KAMFIMEX  still  acts  as  an  agent  for  small  fish 
traders, allowing export under its license, with a fee to cover customs duties and other charges. 
KAMFIMEX  currently  has  103  full-time  staff  and  40  fishermen  associated  with  its  fishing  lot. 
Though it became an autonomous public enterprise in September 2002, KAMFIMEX's financial 
performance has not been made public yet.

Institutional Framework 

19.  MAFF was the lead executing agency for the first ASP and implemented it satisfactorily. 
MAFF  operates  a  standardized  planning  process  using  procedures  that  are  reasonably  well 
established.  MAFF's  current  organizational  structure  was  adopted  in  April  2000  through  a 
subdecree  establishing  12  line  departments.9  Planning  capacities  are  variable  among  MAFF 
departments  partly  because  of  variable  training  and  capacity-building  programs  in  the  past. 
Core  functions  among  the  departments  are  unclear,  particularly  in  the  role  of  policy  planning 
and management, and  due  to  the  mixture  and  overlapping  of  service  delivery  functions.  The 
Government  recognizes  a  strong  need  to  review  the  structure  to  clarify  the  roles  and 
responsibilities  of  these  departments  within  MAFF  in  a  market-oriented agriculture sector. The 
reorganization  of  MAFF  needs  to  be  carried  out  based  on  such  a  review  and  the  renewed 
strategy for human resource development in line with the Government's decentralization policy. 
 
20. 
The Government has been pursuing accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO). 
The action plan to comply with membership conditions in various areas has been implemented 
satisfactorily.  In  July  2003,  WTO  completed  its  work  for  Cambodia's  membership  and 
recommended it in September 2003. The Government has established a task force to address 
WTO  issues  in  the  agriculture  sector.  Several  important  aspects  regarding  harmonization  of

also  established  a  WTO  unit  in  MAFF  to  implement  regulations  and  prepare  new  regulatory 
systems to ensure the quality and safety of agricultural and agro-based products in accordance 
with WTO provisions.

23. 
Under  SEDPII,  the  Government  intends  to  raise  value  added  in  agriculture  by 
diversifying  into  higher-value  products,  and  increasing  downstream  processing  and  related 
services. Undermining this approach are low yields and uncertain quality of products. With the 
country's scarce resources to improve access to agricultural technology, research efforts must 
be client oriented and highly focused on resolving issues that have the most immediate impact 
on the users of research. A national policy for agricultural research and extension was approved 
by the Government in October 1998 to improve the delivery and use of research and extension 
services, dwelling extensively on institutional issues to make them more effective at addressing 
the  critical  issues.  Crucially,  research  institutions  were  to  be  divorced  from  direct  MAFF 
management  to  support  intellectual  independence  and  budgetary  autonomy  to  allow  for 
commitment to medium- and long-term research programs. The national policy also emphasizes 
the  need  to  strengthen  coordination  among  research  institutes,  universities,  government 
agencies and the private sector. 
 
24. 
The  agricultural  extension  services  receive  only  about  2%  of  MAFF's  total  recurrent 
budget despite their importance in improving farm productivity. Inadequate allocation of budget 
for  district  and  provincial  extension  services  hampers  delivery  of  support  services  for  farmers 
and  affects  service  quality.  MAFF's  extension  services  have  been  long  supported  by  the 
Government  of  Australia  since  1995.  Technology  extension  has  also  been  supported  through 
various  area  development  projects  financed  by  other  external  funding  agencies.  However,  as 
the Australian support will be gradually reduced, MAFF urgently requires an increased budget to 
maintain even the current level of support services. Additional resources are also needed at the 
district and provincial levels to complement efforts of area development projects and expand the 
coverage  of  extension  services  to  areas  with  greater  potential  for  commercialized  and 
diversified agriculture. The Government is also trying to raise motivation of extension staff and 
make  them  more  accountable  by  removing  the  system  of  patronage  that  normally  determines 
career development and undermines incentives. 
 

7. 

Current Policy Environment 

25. 
A major thrust of government policy has been towards the decentralization of decision-
making  and  the  deconcentration  of  public  service  delivery,  and  these  have  become  key 
elements  in  the  drive  to  strengthen  governance,  promote  administrative  reforms  and  reduce 
poverty. Before the commune council elections in February 2002, the average Cambodian had 
little  contact  or  knowledge  of  commune-level  administration.  The  election  introduced  a 
representative  level  of  local  government;  11,261  councilors  were  elected  to  1,621  commune 
councils, with 5- 11  members  in  each  council.  Commune  councils  are  still  in  their  infancy  and 

 8 

generally  have  only  one  clerk.10  Efforts  for  deconcentration  of  service  delivery  have  been 
directed at strengthening capacity of line ministries at the provincial level, including for service 
delivery  through  district  offices.  A  number  of  ministries  have  begun  to  assess  the  potential 
service delivery role for commune councils. Accordingly, the current policy of the Government is 
to  fully  take  into  account  the  deconcentration  of  public  service  delivery  in  implementation 
arrangements proposed for new public sector projects in the agriculture sector. 
 
26. 
In 2000 the Government announced its decision to introduce a medium-term expenditure 
framework  (MTEF)  to  budget  planning  in  priority  sectors,  including  the  agriculture  sector.11 
MTEF  aims  to  provide  a  medium-term  rolling  process  and  mechanism  for  continuity  to  link 
development  plans,  multi-year  programs,  and  annual  recurrent  budgets.  This  approach  is 
expected  to  increase  the  effectiveness  of  public  expenditures  in  pursuit  of  development 
objectives. The MTEF approach will be introduced into the agriculture sector for the 2004- 2006 
framework  during  ASDP.  To  make  the  approach  effective,  MAFF's  central  role  in  policy  and 
planning needs to be strengthened in parallel by rationalizing MAFF departments (para. 19).

A. 

Objective and Scope  

1. 

Objective 

31. 
ASDP  aims  to  promote  sustainable  growth  of  the  market-based  agriculture  sector  in 
Cambodia,  and  thereby  contributing  to  overall  economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction. ASDP 
will  facilitate  agricultural  commercialization  and  diversification  in  line  with  SEDPII  and  also 
ensure  that  the  poor  and  women  increasingly  participate  in  agricultural  production,  marketing, 
and post-production system. The program framework is in Appendix 3.

private  agro-based  enterprise  growth,  and  (iii)  strengthen  institutional  capacity  for  competitive 
agricultural commercialization. A development policy letter, describing the Government's reform

62. 
In Cambodia, the potential for rice production to further enhance farmers’ livelihoods is 
limited.  The  small  size  of  landholdings  (usually  less  than  2  ha)  and  low  yields,  combined  with

provincial departments of agriculture, forestry, and fisheries (PDAFFs), the use of farmer groups

b. 

Support Services for Agro-Based Enterprises 

66. 
Cambodia has a large number of micro agroenterprises, each usually comprising a few 
family members and temporary workers. The enterprises are organized as sole proprietorships, 
rarely  registered,  and  do  not  rely  on  formal  credit  for  investment  capital.  To  integrate  farmers 
into rapidly growing urban and international markets, it is important, particularly in rural areas, to 
promote market linkages between farmers and these enterprises and traders. However, growth 
of micro- and small-scale agroenterprises is constrained by weak infrastructure, limited access 
to  credit,  and  limited  information.  No  institutional  framework  provides  relevant  information  on 
their  common  issues  and  business  opportunities.  Even  the  simplest  data  on  how  many 
agroenterprises  operate  in  a  certain  area  and  in  which  field,  and  their  size,  are  not  easily 
available outside Phnom Penh. With the exception of a few NGOs, no institutional mechanism 
provides such business information and services to agroenterprises.

A. 
 
Cambodia's agriculture is dominated by rice cultivation, which takes up about 2.3 million 
1. 
hectares (ha) or 90% of the total cropped area, mainly in the lowland areas along the Mekong

which accounts for about 0.8 million tons (t) or 20% of total rice production of about 4.0 million t, 
is  cultivated  from  December  to  March,  mainly  for  sale,  and  largely  consists  of  high-yielding 
varieties developed under the project supported by the International Rice Research Institute and 
the  Government  of  Australia.  The  yield  of  dry-season  rice  was  estimated  at  about  3.2  t/ha  in 
2001. Wet-season rice, which accounts for about 3.2 million t or 80% of total rice production, is 
usually  cultivated  from  May  to  September, and consists mainly of local varieties for domestic 
consumption.  Average  yield  is  about  1.9  t/ha.  While  the  average  annual  production  growth  of 
dry-season  rice  from  1996  to  2000  (4.8%)  exceeded  that  of  wet  season  rice  (2.8%), 
Cambodians  prefer  the  taste  and  quality  of  local  varieties  and  so  continue  to  grow  them. 
Farmers’  access  to  irrigation  water  is  still  significantly  limited,  with  the  irrigated  area  for  rice 
estimated at about 473,000 ha in 1997/98 or about 16% of the total rice area, which is mostly for 
supplementary  wet-season irrigation.  During  the  past  decade,  the  country  has  become  self-
sufficient in rice and is able to export a modest surplus. Even though the exact amount of this 
surplus  is  not  known  due  to  the  largely  informal  nature  of  the  rice  trade,  it  is  estimated  that 
about 400,000 t of paddy and about 50,000 t of milled rice were exported in 2001. 
 
2. 
Other major crops are maize (71,500 ha), vegetables (33,800 ha), soybean (33,300 ha), 
mung  bean  (25,000  ha),  sesame  (19,200  ha),  cassava  (16,300  ha),  peanut  (10,400  ha), 
sugarcane  (7,700  ha),  and  sweet  potato  (7,400  ha).  Maize  production  grew  rapidly  at  an 
average rate of about 11% per annum from 1991 to 2000, particularly as a result of improved 
yields and increasing demand for animal feed due to the rapid growth of the poultry industry in

is  highly  advantageous  for  Cambodia.  Maize  is  mainly  produced  in  Kampong  Cham Province

mung beans at 1.7% over the decade masks a strong decline of 5.0% over the last five years,

directly  offshore.  Total  catch  in  2001  was  about  194,500  t  (135,000  inland,  42,000  marine, 
17,500 aquaculture). 
 
8. 
Fishery  is  a  significant  export,  amounting  to  about  $4  million  in  2001.  Exports  and 
production  fluctuate  widely  year  on  year,  but  catches  have  grown  at  about  4%  per  annum  on 
average  over  the  last  5  years.  In  the  past,  exports  were  totally  controlled  by  the  Kampuchea 
Fishery Import and Export (KAMFIMEX), a government agency. It was turned into a financially 
autonomous  state-owned  enterprise  in  September  2002,  and  needs  to  compete  with  other 
private enterprises on an equal footing with the private sector. Fishing has been regulated by a 
system  of  fishing  concessions  or  lots.  Recently,  the  number  of  lots  has  been  reduced 
substantially  (from  235  covering  about  1  million  ha,  to  164  covering  around  400,000  ha).  The 
objective is to release more than half the fishing lots to local communities. The mechanism to 
manage these community fisheries is being determined. Aquaculture has also increasingly been 
supported at the village level and has grown at about 9% per annum over the last decade, and 
now accounts for about 10% of marketed production. Processing is constrained  by the lack of 
constant  supplies,  a  situation  more  acute  for  freshwater  than  marine  fisheries,  although  the 
latter are also affected by inshore poaching by unlicensed foreign vessels. 
 
9. 
Forestry  has  declined  in  importance  in  recent  years  largely  because  of  the  ban  on  the 
export of logs starting in 1996 and revocation of forest concessions.3 In 2001 forestry accounted 
for only 6% of the country's agricultural gross domestic product compared with over 12% before 
the  First  Socioeconomic  Development  Plan  (1996–2000)  period.  There  is  an  urgent  need  to 
introduce  a  mechanism  for  sustainable  management  of  forest  resources  agreeable  to  all  key 
stakeholders. Community forests, which constitute still less than 1% of the total forest area, are 
being promoted, but are still restricted due to complications associated with land titling.

Vision for Agriculture in Cambodia 

D. 
 
17. 
Cambodia is now self-sufficient in rice and is constantly exporting rice surplus. Increased 
rice  production  has  helped  improve  food  security  and  set  the  basis  for  agricultural 
commercialization  and  diversification,  which  constitute  the  main  strategic  thrust  of  the 
Government's Second Socioeconomic Development Plan. However, the achievements are still 
fragile because agriculture largely depends on rainfall. Weak water control and lack of improved 
technology make smallholders vulnerable to the vagaries of the weather. Yet, the country is at a 
crucial  moment,  when  strategic  decisions  need  to  be  made  in  relation  to  the  future  vision  of 
agriculture in the medium- to long-term. In this vision, rice will continue to be the main crop in 
terms  of  cultivated  areas,  but  the  importance  of  rice  in  terms  of  value  added  within  the  sector 
will  decline.  The  share  of  higher  value-added  products  such  as  non-rice crops, fisheries, and 
livestock  has  a  potential  to  increase  as  a  result  of  closer  integration  with  domestic  and 
international markets. Agricultural products may become a driving force for sustainable growth 
and allow Cambodia to benefit from its membership in the World Trade Organization. This vision 
will clearly require concerted efforts to facilitate commercialization of agriculture, diversification 
toward higher-value products, and integration of smallholders with agro-based enterprises. 
 
18. 
To achieve this vision for the agriculture sector, the Government will continue the policy 
and  institutional  reforms  initiated  under  the  first  Agriculture  Sector  Program  (1996–2000) and 
address  remaining  sector  issues  to  (i)  improve  ability  of  smallholders  to  raise  productivity  and 
diversify towards higher-value products, (ii) improve market environment for private agro-based 
enterprise  growth,  and  (iii)  strengthen  institutional  capacity  for  competitive  agricultural 
commercialization.  The  Government  will  also  promote  participation  of  the  poor  and  women  in 
agricultural  production,  marketing,  and  post-production  system  to  enhance  the  impact  of 
agricultural growth on sustainability and poverty reduction.

A. 
 
Poverty  in  Cambodia  largely  results  from  high  population  growth,  inadequate  income 
1.

constrained by cyclic and chronic problems leading to increased poverty. Low agricultural value-
added  growth  implies  low  income  for  farmers,  who  make  up  most  of  rural  population.  Low 
growth  and  uncertainty  also  imply  reduced  incentives  to  invest  in  the  sector,  thus  weakening 
linkages with the rest of the rural economy and compromising the sector's future sustainability. 
In December 2002 the Government formulated the National Poverty Reduction Strategy (NPRS) 
in  line  with  the  Second  Socioeconomic  Development  Plan  (SEDPII),  and  emphasized  the 
importance of the agriculture sector in maximizing food self-sufficiency and increasing income-
generating  opportunities.  In  the  agriculture  sector,  the  Government  will  implement  pro-poor 
strategies to target provinces with high incidence of poverty and food insecurity. 
 
The  Agriculture  Sector  Development  Program  (ASDP)  will  facilitate  policy  reforms  in 
2. 
three  areas:  (i)  improve  farmers  ability  to  raise  productivity  and  diversify  toward  high-value 
products,  (ii)  improve  the  market  environment  for  private  agro-based  enterprises,  and  (iii) 
strengthen  institutional  capacity  for  competitive  agricultural  commercialization.  All  these 
measures  will  have  some  direct  or  indirect  impact  on  poverty  reduction.  The  first  policy  area 
addresses  improvement  of  legal  and  regulatory  aspects  of  productive  resources  and  input 
supply, access, and use, with emphasis on poor and low-income farmers. By improving access 
to and use of non-rice land, smallholder investment can be encouraged through secure tenure. 
Farm production may be increased through improved  access to and use of irrigation water and 
quality  seed,  fertilizer  and  chemicals  in  input  markets.  The  poor  are  expected  to  be  major 
beneficiaries  in  the  short  to  medium  term  particularly  of  measures  related  to  land  tenure  and 
linkage  opportunities.  The  poor  will  also  benefit  from  quality  agricultural  inputs,  provided  they 
are affordable.

Women are generally disadvantaged in accessing  essential services and resources to 
overcome  poverty,  particularly  in  education  (women's  literacy  rate  is  61%,  considerably  lower 
than men's 83%). Rural women have a higher risk of ill health and bear a substantial burden in 
agricultural  production  in  addition  to  household  duties.  Women  constitute  more  than  half  the 
farming  population  and  carry  out  most  of  the  rice  transplanting  and  harvesting.  They  are  also 
responsible  for  seed  selection,  and  milling  and  pounding  for  household  consumption.  Women 
work an average of 25- 45% longer than men each day. Women often tend vegetable gardens 
for home consumption and for sale. Men are normally responsible for the care of large livestock, 
and women for small livestock. The gender division of labor is not entirely rigid  but men expect 
to be paid more for remunerative activities than women because of claimed physical strength. 
 
6. 
Women  carry  out  well  over  90%  of  reproductive  and  household  duties,  including  the 
caring for not only the very young and the aged but also, in some cases, adults who are ill or 
disabled.  Social  obligations  are  important  and  time  consuming.  Women  do  not  get  public 
recognition for their supportive role, especially in preparing food for the numerous cultural and 
religious rituals. Women also provide much of the community work, such as ensuring the daily 
feeding  of  monks  or  the  logistics  to  organize  a  major  temple  festival.  Women  and  men  have 
equal rights to legally own land. However, distress sales of land (due to loan default and other 
hardships) among poor female-headed households have been over double that of male-headed 
households.  Access  to  affordable  credit  and  other  income-generating  opportunities,  including 
wage  labor,  is  limited.  Participation  of  women  in  the  political and public sectors remains low 
from the commune to national level. Female extension workers are less than one third of total 
staff complement. The situation is even worse at the MAFF central office, while slightly better in 
provincial  departments  of  agriculture,  forestry,  and  fisheries.  Female  students  are  under- 
represented in all institutions that offer tertiary education in agriculture.

FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC ANALYSES 

Introduction 

Program Component 

 
A. 
 
The  Agriculture  Sector  Development  Program  (ASDP)  consists  of  policy-based program 
1. 
and investment project components. This section discusses the financial and economic benefits of 
ASDP  expected  under  these  two  components.  A  narrative  assessment  has  been  done for the 
program  component  although  preliminary  estimates  are  also  indicated  for  the  adjustment  costs 
required for major policy and institutional reforms. With regard to the project component, financial 
and  economic  analyses  have  been  carried  out  quantitatively on the incremental cost and benefit 
streams of the extension support for farmer groups. 
 
B. 
 
2. 
The  program  component  combines  efforts  to  liberalize  key  agricultural  markets,  and 
focuses  on  institutional  reform  and  strengthening.  Institutional  reforms  are  a  medium-term 
process  given  the  time  required  to  establish  institutional  systems,  build  staff  capacity,  monitor 
agricultural  trades,  and  implement  regulations  nationwide,  and  to  realign  budgets  to  deliver 
decentralized support services. 
 
The  benefits  associated  with  improved  access  to  land  will  be  generated  from  increased 
3. 
security of land property rights, which will provide incentives to poor and landless farmers to make 
unused  land  productive.  Several  farmers  are  already  living  on  the  land  envisaged  in  social  land 
concession  programs  or  borders  of  economic  concession  lands.  This  is  in  fact,  one  of  the  main 
reasons for the failure of economic concessions that were given without considering the needs of 
local communities or landless people. The costs required for the reforms on land concessions will 
include  those  for  rural  development  support  for  the  beneficiaries  of  social  land  concessions  to 
sustain  their  livelihoods.  The  Government's  social  land  concession  programs  will  not  be 
effective  unless  accompanied  by  land  titling  and  agricultural  support  services  to  newly  titled 
smallholders. The rural development support costs for the program will include those for land-
use surveys, titling, agricultural extension support and infrastructure. There will also be costs for 
increased public awareness campaigns on the subdecree for social land concessions and the 
2001  Land  Law.  Compensation  payments  may  be  also  required  to  defray  investment costs of 
the developers of unused and subsequently revoked economic concessions. 
 
4. 
The expected benefits generated from divestment of state-owned rubber estates are of 
two  types.  The  first  relates  to  the  lower  cost  of  production  resulting  from  more  efficient 
enterprises and work force. The second type relates to additional investment in new assets and 
the consequent increase in future revenues generated from higher profits from rubber or other 
products. Cost efficiency will be realized gradually one over the medium term. In the short run, 
there  may  be  costs  required  to  provide  compensation  packages  for  some  redundant  staff.  To 
effect divestment of rubber estates, redundancy packages and provision of support services for 
displaced workers may be required, for which the program loan will generate counterpart funds. 
 
Benefits  expected  from  strengthening  of  agricultural  institutions  are  mostly  indirect  and 
5. 
to be generated from a more effective role of the public sector to facilitate the market-oriented 
agricultural  growth.  Rationalization  of  the  institutional  functions  of  the  Ministry  of  Agriculture, 
Forestry and Fisheries (MAFF) will require staff training to be provided under the project loan. In 
addition, the program loan will support the expanded role and geographic coverage of MAFF in 
regulating  quality  of  seeds,  fertilizers,  and  agrochemicals,  as  well  as  in  providing  market 
information services.

6. 
The  Government  decided  to  introduce  a  medium-term expenditure framework (MTEF) 
for budget planning in priority sectors, including the agriculture sector.1 This will strengthen the 
linkage between annual expenditures for the sector and overall development plans such as the 
Second  Socioeconomic  Development  Plan  (SEDPII)  and  the  National  Poverty  Reduction 
Strategy.  In  view  of  the  importance  of  the  agriculture  sector,  the  allocation  of  public 
expenditures  for  the  sector  needs  to  increase  rapidly  in  line  with  SEDPII. 2  The  overall  budget 
ceiling for the agriculture sector needs to increase from about 2% to the range of 5–10%, which 
is the level adopted for other priority sectors. It is estimated that an incremental budget of about 
$20  million  will  be  required  for  the  agriculture  sector  in  the  medium  term.  During  ASDP 
implementation, ADB will continue its dialogue with the Government for strengthening the MTEF 
for  the  agriculture  sector,  and  promote  adequate  fiscal  allocations  to  facilitate  agricultural 
growth.  ASDP  will  also  improve  the  country's  fiscal  situation  through  potential  revenue 
collections and increased efficiency in the agriculture sector. 
 
7. 
Under the program component, ASDP will also contribute to benefit distribution in favor 
of  the  poor  through  (i)  increased  public  awareness  of  the  legal  framework  related  to  the  2001 
Land  Law  and  related  subdecrees,  (ii)  progress  in  implementing  social  land  concession 
programs  for  the  poor,  (iii)  divestment  of  state-owned  rubber  estates  and  other  public 
enterprises  that  will  benefit  rubber  smallholders  and  small-scale  enterprises  in  the  private 
sector,  and  (iv)  increased  fiscal  resources  to  local  administrations  to  deliver  public  agricultural 
extension services. 
 
C. 
 
 
 
8. 
Financial and economic analyses were carried out for the project component of ASDP 
based  on  typical  cropping  patterns  in  the  project  area,  and  expected  aggregate  costs  and 
benefits.  It  is  assumed  that  the  project  benefits  are  expected  from  farmers'  adoption  of  new 
technology  through  extension  support  for  farmer  groups.  Other  benefits  indirectly  generated 
from  ASDP's  program  component  and  other  project  activities  relating  to  support  services  for 
agro-based  enterprises  and  institutional  capacity  building  will  significantly  enhance  project 
benefits  but  have  not  been  quantified  in  the  analyses.  The  economic  life  of  the  project  is 
assumed to be 20 years. The prices of project inputs and outputs are those prevailing during the 
surveys conducted in June 2002 in the project area.3

2. 

Cropping Patterns 

 
11. 
Gradual  changes  in  cropping  patterns  are  expected  under  the  project  through  farmers' 
increased adoption of new agricultural technology and commercial crops. In a few villages in the 
project  provinces,  rapid  changes  have  been  achieved  by  nongovernment  organizations  and 
under  the  Special  Programme  for  Food  Security  initiated  by  the  Government  with  assistance 
from the Food and Agriculture Organization. The project area is mostly in the rain-fed lowland 
region  where  most  farmers  cultivate  rain-fed  paddy  during  May–September.5 According to the 
field survey conducted in the project provinces during preparation of ASDP, at least about 70% 
of  cropped  area  is  devoted  to  rice.  Non-rice  crops  include  corn  and  other  cereals,  various 
vegetables, beans, pulses, and fruits. 
 
12. 
The  project  will  promote  more  efficient  and  commercially  viable  cropping  patterns  by 
increasing access to improved inputs, and information on technology and marketing.  Both non-
poor and poor farmers are expected to gradually change their cropping patterns and introduce 
commercial  production.  Farmers  will  modify  commercial  cropping  patterns  more  frequently  in 
response  to  changes  in  local  market  conditions.  With  improved  access to extension services 
and market information, farmers and their groups will be able to make more informed decisions 
and  adopt  more  efficient  farming  practices.  Cropping  intensity  is  expected  to  increase  slightly 
but remain almost stable in the medium term.
